questions.text: The most common sequelae of tuberculous spondylitis are?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bony Ankylosis Tuberculous spondylitis is most commonly localized in the thoracic portion of the spine. The infection coming from the primary site (ie: lungs) then spreads from two adjacent vertebrae into the adjoining intervertebral disc space. If only one vertebra is affected, the disc is normal, but if two are involved, the avascular disc, cannot receive nutrients and collapses. The disc tissue dies and is broken down by caseation, leading to vertebral narrowing and eventually to vertebral collapse (Bony ankylosis) and spinal damage. From the choices given in the question, the most logical answer is bony ankylosis. The most common cause of bony ankylosis: Septic arthritis >TB spine

questions.text: The most commonly performed surgery for Pott's paraplegia is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterolateral decompression All of the following surgeries can be performed in the case of Pott’s paraplegia but the most commonly performed surgery to relieve paraplegia is an Anterolateral decompression. Here, the spine is opened from its lateral side and access is made to the front and side of the cord, thus called antero-lateral decompression. Structures are removed in the following order to achieve adequate exposure: ribs, transverse process, pedicle, and part of the body of the vertebrae. If Lamina or facet joints are not removed, otherwise the stability of the joint will be seriously jeopardized. Indications for operative management: Advanced disease with marked bone destruction with threatened acute Kyphosis or Paraparesis. Neurological complications not improving in 3-6 weeks. For mechanical stability of spine Recurrence in neural complications. Surgeries that can be done Costotransversectomy (limited role) Anterior/Anterolateral decompression of spine Arthrodesis of spine Laminectomy

questions.text: A 29-year-old man gives a 24-hour history of pain in his index finger. The finger is swollen and is held in a flexed position. It is very tender on palpation of the volar surface, and pain is exacerbated by the passive extension of the finger. What is the underlying diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Suppurative flexor tenosynovitis This clinical scenario describes an infection of the flexor tendon sheath. Kanavel described four cardinal signs of infectious tenosynovitis: Swelling along the entire flexor surface; Tenderness over the course of the tendon sheath; Pain on passive extension of the finger; An inability to straighten the finger at rest.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. FELON. It is an infection of the subcutaneous tissues of the distal pulp of a finger or thumb. There are multiple small fibrous septa which divide the pulp into various compartments. The infection is usually caused by penetrating injury like a finger prick for estimation of blood glucose level. Option: B. PARONYCHIA Paronychia means “run around”. It is caused by S. aureus in the soft-tissue fold around the fingernail (eponychium). These are associated with a hung nails or poor nail hygiene. When an abscess forms at one corner of the defective or horny nail it travels under either the eponychium or the nail and spreads toward the opposite side. Clinical features are pain, tenderness, and swelling on one or both sides of nail folds and may also be present at the base of the nail. Option: C. This clinical scenario describes an infection of the flexor tendon sheath, Kanavel signs positive

questions.text: All the following are known complications of chronic osteomyelitis except which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adenocarcinoma Adenocarcinoma is not a complication of chronic osteomyelitis, squamous cell carcinoma occurs due to sinus tract malignancy

Highyeild:

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS Conventionally, the term 'chronic osteomyelitis' is used for chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis. Although, its incidence is on the decline in developed countries, it continues to be an important problem in developing countries. The other causes of chronic osteomyelitis are tuberculosis, fungal infections etc. There are three types of chronic osteomyelitis: Chronic osteomyelitis secondary to acute osteomyelitis. Garre's osteomyelitis. Brodie's abscess. PATHOLOGY Acute osteomyelitis commonly leads to chronic osteomyelitis because of one or more of the following reasons: Delayed and inadequate treatment: This is the commonest cause for the persistence of an osteomyelitis. Delay causes spread of pus within the medullary cavity and sub- periosteally. This results in the death of a part of the bone (sequestrum formation). Destruction of cancellous bone leads to the formation of cavities within the bone. Such 'non-collapsing" bone cavities and sequestra are responsible for persistent infection. Type and virulence of organism: Sometimes, despite early, adequate treatment of acute osteomyelitis, the body's defense mechanism may not be able to control the damaging influence of a highly virulent organism, and the infection persists. Reduced host resistance: Malnutrition compromises the body's defense mechanisms, thus letting the infection persist. COMPLICATIONS OF CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS: Arthritis Skeletal deformations Malignant transformation (eg, Marjolin ulcer [squamous cell carcinoma], SCC of the sinus tract) S econdary amyloidosis P athologic fractures

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. In chronic osteomyelitis, Pathological fracture may occur through a weakened area of the bone. Treatment is by conservative methods Option: C. As with all other long-standing suppurations, Amyloidosis is a late complication of chronic osteomyelitis Option: D. Septicemia is a complication of chronic osteomyelitis

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents to the outpatient department with the chief complaints of right hip pain and limp for the last 2 days. Further history reveals that the patient is having a high-grade fever which has been documented by her parents (102 degrees F). On examination, there is swelling around the right hip anteriorly and the local temperature is raised. There is no sinus, scar or active pus discharge. Tenderness is present around the hip anteriorly with a restricted range of motion. Baseline investigations reveal a TLC of 16, 400 with neutrophilia. ESR is 120 mm/hr and CRP levels are 22 mg/dl. Radiographs are unremarkable. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Septic Hip The clinical features and baseline investigations confirm the diagnosis of a septic hip. The septic hip is a common infectious condition seen in children. The presence of fever, tenderness and restricted range of motion point more towards septic arthritis. Acute Diagnosis is mainly clinical. Kocher criteria can be used to differentiate from transient synovitis. The patient is usually a child. The knee is the commonest joint affected. Other joints commonly affected are the hip, shoulder, elbow etc.

AOM of the proximal femur is also a possibility but given that the range of motion is restricted with no tenderness localized to the proximal femur rules it out. Option: C. In addition, the radiographs in the COM femur will show characteristic features of formation sequestrum, involucrum, and/or cloaca may be seen. Option: D. Transient synovitis is unlikely as the clinical predictor algorithms have been used to differentiate transient synovitis from septic arthritis in children. C-reactive protein greater than 20 mg/L and inability to bear weight rule out the diagnosis of transient synovitis.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Staphylococcus aureus Staphylococcus aureus is the commonest causative organism. Others are Streptococcus and Pneumococcus. These organisms reach the bone via blood circulation. The primary focus of infection is generally not detectable. The bacteria, as they pass through the bone, get lodged in the metaphysis. The lower femoral metaphysis is the commonest site. The other common sites are the upper tibial, upper femoral and upper humeral metaphyses. Most common organism in sickle cell anaemia is salmonella.
